title: Friedreich's ataxia
summary: Friedreich's ataxia (FRDA or FA) is an autosomal-recessive genetic disease that causes difficulty walking, a loss of sensation in the arms and legs, and impaired speech that worsens over time. Symptoms generally start between 5 and 20 years of age. Many develop hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and require a mobility aid such as a cane, walker, or wheelchair in their teens.   As the disease progresses, some affected people lose their sight and hearing. Other complications may include scoliosis and diabetes mellitus.
